system.description:
General

Humans are the standard for the game, and as such, humans have no unusual abilities or limitations in game terms. Because of their potential for unlimited progression in all the character classes save assassin and druid, humans are a popular choice for most players. This is an intentional feature of the rules.

A common house rule in OSRIC-compatible games is the adjustment or removal of demi-human level limits. This will unbalance the game in favour of demi-humans unless humans are given some corresponding advantage. GMs considering such a house rule for their own OSRIC-compatible games are advised to ensure that in most campaigns, humans should still represent an attractive choice for their players.

 

Movement Rate: 120 ft

 

Starting Age:

Cleric [[/roll 20+1d4]]
Fighter [[/roll 15+1d4]]
Mage [[/roll 24+2d8]]
Thief [[/roll 20+1d4]]

[Foundry Note: sub-classes are as main class. - Ed.]

 

Level Limitations:

Assassin 15
Cleric Unlimited
Druid 14
Fighter Unlimited
Illusionist Unlimited
Magic User Unlimited
Paladin Unlimited
Ranger Unlimited
Thief Unlimited

[Foundry Note:  This "weapon" is included in the non-lethal skill bundle and doesn't require a separate drop on an actor sheet. 

All characters can put this "weapon" in their inventory just as they would a dagger, etc.   All characters are proficient in all forms of unarmed combat without spending weapon proficiences; attach the like-named proficiency that comes with all classes to the weapon without having to spend any points.]

Unarmed combat: Brawling attacks, such as those conducted with fist, foot, or dagger pommel, will normally inflict [[/roll 1d2]] points of damage.

[ Note: All characters can put this "weapon" in their inventory just as they would a dagger, etc.   All characters are proficient in all forms of unarmed combat without spending weapon proficiences; attach the like-named proficiency that comes with all classes to the weapon without having to spend any points.]

Unarmed combat - grapple: A successful grappling attack inflicts 0-1 ([[/roll 1d2-1]]) points of damage, but also restrains the target and prevents him or her from fighting. The chance of breaking a successful grapple should be determined according to the relative strengths of the creatures concerned. (An ogre could restrain a kobold almost indefinitely, and would be able to break free of the kobold's grasp at will.)

actionGroups.name: Grapple: Restrained

[ Note: All characters can put this "weapon" in their inventory just as they would a dagger, etc.   All characters are proficient in all forms of unarmed combat without spending weapon proficiences; attach the like-named proficiency that comes with all classes to the weapon without having to spend any points.]

Unarmed combat - grapple: A successful grappling attack inflicts 0-1 ([[/roll 1d2-1]]) points of damage, but also restrains the target and prevents him or her from fighting. The chance of breaking a successful grapple should be determined according to the relative strengths of the creatures concerned. (An ogre could restrain a kobold almost indefinitely, and would be able to break free of the kobold's grasp at will.)

system.description:
[ Note: All characters can put this "weapon" in their inventory just as they would a dagger, etc.   All characters are proficient in all forms of unarmed combat without spending weapon proficiences; attach the like-named proficiency that comes with all classes to the weapon without having to spend any points.]

Unarmed combat - overbearing: Overbearing attacks are Grappling attacks exercised at the end of a Charge (see "Charge" above). If successful, the opponent is prone rather than restrained. Otherwise the attack is treated as a grapple.

Referenced Text: A successful grappling attack inflicts 0-1 ([[/roll 1d2-1]]) points of damage, but also restrains the target and prevents him or her from fighting. The chance of breaking a successful grapple should be determined according to the relative strengths of the creatures concerned. (An ogre could restrain a kobold almost indefinitely, and would be able to break free of the kobold's grasp at will.)

Referenced Text: Charge: Charging into combat allows the attacker to move and then attack in the same round. A charge is made at twice the normal movement rate (and must terminate within the 10-ft melee range of the target). If the defender has a longer weapon than the attacker, the defender attacks first (unless the defender has already acted in this round). The attacker gains no dexterity bonus against such an attack (and characters with no dexterity bonus receive a +1 AC penalty). Additionally, if the defender has a weapon set against the charge (see below), he or she will inflict additional damage with a successful hit against the charging attacker.

Assuming that the charging character survives, he or she gains +2 "to hit" on his or her attack. Characters may only perform a charge once every 10 rounds (i.e. once per turn). Characters who are at the maximum encumbrance category may not charge unless they are mounted and the mount is below the maximum encumbrance category.

Unarmed combat - overbearing: Overbearing attacks are Grappling attacks exercised at the end of a Charge (see "Charge" above). If successful, the opponent is prone rather than restrained. Otherwise the attack is treated as a grapple.

Referenced Text: A successful grappling attack inflicts 0-1 ([[/roll 1d2-1]]) points of damage, but also restrains the target and prevents him or her from fighting. The chance of breaking a successful grapple should be determined according to the relative strengths of the creatures concerned. (An ogre could restrain a kobold almost indefinitely, and would be able to break free of the kobold's grasp at will.)

A charge is made at twice the normal movement rate (and must terminate within the 10-ft melee range of the target). If the defender has a longer weapon than the attacker, the defender attacks first (unless the defender has already acted in this round). The attacker gains no dexterity bonus against such an attack (and characters with no dexterity bonus receive a +1 AC penalty). Additionally, if the defender has a weapon set against the charge (see below), he or she will inflict additional damage with a successful hit against the charging attacker.

Assuming that the charging character survives, he or she gains +2 "to hit" on his or her attack. Characters may only perform a charge once every 10 rounds (i.e. once per turn). Characters who are at the maximum encumbrance category may not charge unless they are mounted and the mount is below the maximum encumbrance category.

system.description:
Thieves and assassins have an enhanced chance to hear noise as they gain levels (see “thief skills” in Chapter I). Characters of all other classes have a base 10% chance. This should be modified by race; elves, gnomes, halflings, and half-orcs have a base 15% chance.  (In Foundry, these races have a 5% bonus added to their skill check target number automatically when the skill is used- Ed.)

 

Hear - Base Chance/Target Formula

Assassin Thief
Level  Target Range Level Target Range
1 10% 1 10%
2 10% 2 13%
3 10% 3 16%
4 13% 4 19%
5 16% 5 22%
6 19% 6 25%
7 22% 7 28%
8 25% 8 31%
9 28% 9 34%
10 31% 10 37%
11 34% 11 40%
12 37% 12 43%
13 40% 13 46%
14 43% 14 49%
15 46% 15 52%
    16 55%
    17 58%
    18 61%
    19 64%
    20 67%
    21 70%
    22 73%
    23 76%
    24 79%

 

Normally the GM rolls this die in secret, because the player has no way of knowing whether no noise was heard because of the roll or because there was no noise to hear. A character who fails (or thinks he or she has failed) to hear noise may try again, each attempt taking one round. However, no more than three attempts may be made the same character before the strain becomes too great and no further listening attempts will succeed until the character has rested for at least one turn.

If the check is successful, the GM should decide whether there is in fact any noise to be heard. Some monsters, such as bugbears, are stealthy and cannot be detected by listening. However, generally if there is some monster in the area and a “hear noise” check is passed, the party should gain some clue about what it is. Clever players whose characters speak various monster languages may gain valuable information from overhearing snatches of conversation—but the GM should be careful only to describe what characters can actually hear. So the GM would not normally say “you hear a giant spider,” but rather “you hear a scuttling, rattling sound” as the creature climbs to a suitable spot from which to ambush the party.

Don’t forget, monsters can hear the party in the same way as the party can hear them!
system.dmonlytext:
Listening for noise as often as possible, at every door and intersection, is an understandably common tactic, because it’s one of the easiest ways for players to improve the odds in their favour — so as to be able to make better-informed decisions about their actions. This is fine in moderation. However, if the pace of play slows considerably, diminishing the excitement and reducing the adventure to dice-rolling, the GM should discourage the players from endless listening attempts. Emphasise the inconvenience of donning and doffing helmets and headgear while the rest of the party stands around doing nothing; and if play is still slow, employ tricks that circumvent listening, e.g. silent monsters or phantom noises (perhaps due to strange acoustics in the dungeon or magic). In extreme cases the GM can place traps and monsters that specifically target listening characters, but before it gets to that, the GM should speak frankly to the players and explain that while some degree of caution is good play, carrying things to extremes only makes the game less fun.

Balance this against the lethality of the dungeon. In extremely dangerous areas, the players should not be punished for taking due care.

system.description: This is used to determine success on minor feats of strength such as forcing a dungeon door that doesn't open easily (this is the average dungeon door).
This is used to attempt an extraordinary success on minor feats of strength such as forcing a dungeon door enspelled by minor magics such as Hold Portal or Wizard Lock.
[Foundry Note: your GM likely will require this skill to be rolled as GM private. - Ed.]

General

When the clash of steel rings out in dark forests or dimly lit dungeons beneath the earth, it is the fighter who bears the brunt of the combat. Fighters are trained in the use of weapons and armour, usually beginning their adventuring careers after a stint of training as a town guardsman, soldier, man at arms, bandit, pirate, or mercenary.

Fighters are the backbone of an adventuring party; without them to hold the line, the other members of the party will be overrun before they can bring their own skills to bear. Fighters are the most powerful characters in melee or missile combat, whether on offence or defence. Together with the ranger and paladin, they have the most hit points, and their ability to survive the most brutal battles is therefore unrivalled.

They also have the best chance "to hit" of all the classes, particularly at higher level. They may use any kind of armour, shield, or weapon.

Most fighters look forward to the day when their reputations will bring them into the ranks of the lesser nobility, where fighting prowess and armed followers are more important than high-flown bloodlines. It is no small matter to carve a freehold out of the wilderness, but to do so is to leave behind a legacy in a world where most fortune-seekers die an unsung death.

A fighter of 9th level or higher who has built a castle and cleared a wide area around it of monsters (at least a 20 mile radius), will attract a body of mercenaries to his or her service, provided that these are paid a fair wage. He or she will also be able to tax each freeholder, at up to the maximum rate of 1 gp per month per resident.

Some players may choose to retire a character at this point, satisfied that the character has entered the historical records and legends of the campaign world. Others may choose to view the stronghold merely as the first step toward the pinnacles of mythic power. Such player-held castles and villages provide a higher-level party with a base for adventures, a stronghold against enemies, and possibly the introduction of feudal politics and war into their already-eventful lives.

 

Minimum Scores: Str 9, Dex 6, Con 7, Int 3, Wis 6, Cha 6

 

Hit Die Type: d10 (max 9 hit dice)

 

Alignment: Any

 

Experience bonus: Strength 16+

 

Armour/Shield Permitted: Any

 

Weapons Permitted: Any

 

Weapon Proficiencies: 4, +1 every 2 levels

 

Penalty to hit for non-proficiency: -2

 

Weapon Specialisation: Optional

 

Fighter Class Abilities

 

Bonus Attacks: Fighters with melee weapons attack once per round at 1st to 6th levels (1/1 attacks); at 7th to 12th levels, they attack thrice every two rounds (3/2 attacks); and at 13th or higher levels they attack twice per round (2/1 attacks).

A partial additional attack (e.g. 3/2 attacks) means that the extra attack is taken on odd-numbered rounds in the combat sequence, hence two attacks on the first round, one on the second, two on the third and one on the fourth, if applicable.

 

Fighting the Unskilled: When the fighter is attacking creatures with less than a full hit die (i.e. less than [[/roll 1d8]] hit points), the fighter receives one attack for each of his or her levels of experience, e.g. a 4th-level fighter attacking goblins would receive 4 attacks per round.

NB: A fighter exercising multiple attacks departs from the normal initiative procedure. The fighter will automatically attack first in the round unless fighting an opponent with multiple attacks of its own (in which case initiative should be rolled as normal). The fighter's second attack in any given melee round will come last in the sequence.

 

Weapon Specialisation (optional): With the permission of the GM, weapon specialisation may be selected during character generation. If weapon specialisation is not selected during character generation, it remains forever unavailable to the character, barring some magical or divine intervention.

If weapon specialisation is in play, fighters may take a second proficiency in the same weapon as the first, granting them one extra attack every 2 rounds with the weapon (hence 3/2 attacks with a melee weapon at 1st level, 2/1 at 7th and 5/2 at 13th), +1 to hit and +2 damage owing to their skill.

Specialisation costs one proficiency "slot" for melee weapons and crossbows, and two "slots" for missile weapons other than crossbows.

 

Double Specialisation (optional): For melee weapons that are not polearms or two-handed swords, a third weapon proficiency may be used to specialise further; this increases combat bonuses to +3 to hit and +3 damage with the weapon.

 

Optional Rule: Where a fighter of extremely high level or with many bonuses "to hit" actually requires a negative score to hit his or her target, then at the GM's option, the negative score may be converted to a positive and applied as additional damage to the automatic hit. Thus, for example, a 20th level fighter with 19 strength and a +5 sword attacking an AC 2 dragon would require a roll of -8 to hit it; the character would be allowed to modify his or her damage roll by +8.

Where a fighter of extremely high level or with many bonuses "to hit" actually requires a negative score to hit his or her target, then at the GM's option, the negative score may be converted to a positive and applied as additional damage to the automatic hit. Thus, for example, a 20th level fighter with 19 strength and a +5 sword attacking an AC 2 dragon would require a roll of -8 to hit it; the character would be allowed to modify his or her damage roll by +8.

When the fighter is attacking creatures with less than a full hit die (i.e. less than 1d8 hit points), the fighter receives one attack for each of his or her levels of experience, e.g. a 4th-level fighter attacking goblins would receive 4 attacks per round.

Fighters with melee weapons attack once per round at 1st to 6th levels (1/1 attacks); at 7th to 12th levels, they attack thrice every two rounds (3/2 attacks); and at 13th or higher levels they attack twice per round (2/1 attacks). A partial additional attack (e.g. 3/2 attacks) means that the extra attack is taken on odd-numbered rounds in the combat sequence, hence two attacks on the first round, one on the second, two on the third and one on the fourth, if applicable.

Paladins and rangers gain additional attacks as fighters do, but less swiftly. A paladin has one attack at 1st to 7th level, 3/2 attacks at 8th to 14th level, and two attacks at 15th level and above.

A character exercising multiple attacks departs from the normal initiative procedure. The character will automatically attack first in the round unless fighting an opponent with multiple attacks of its own (in which case initiative should be rolled as normal). The character's second attack in any given melee round will come last in the sequence.

Allowed Classes

Any

 

Details

Also known as the "luckstone," this item grants +1 to all saving throws and "to hit" rolls.

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.4bEHV1JR3K4cMXMl]{Rings - Chance of Failure (Dwarf, Gnome, Halfling)}

[Foundry Note: an aura effect provides the ring's benefits to any allies within a 5 ft radius of the ring wearer.  There isn't a way to differentiate the bonus if someone is wearing magic armour but allies aren't, or vice-versa. A second aura is given that is "save only" for ring-wearers in magic armour  - Ed.]

 

Allowed Classes

Any

 

Details

This useful item increases the wearer's AC and saving throw vs all forms of attack. The protective properties of the ring are cumulative with other forms of protection (Bless, for instance) subject to the following limitations:

  • if magic armour is worn the wearer's AC will not be increased, though the saving throw bonus will still apply.
  • Also, only one ring of protection may be worn at a time. If two are worn, the stronger of the two will function.
system.dmonlytext:
XP/GP Value

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables-gm.RollTable.bhTLYvZJqwDj6qZA]{Magic Ring-as-Jewellery Value}

 

Apparent (Jewellery) Value: ?

(True) GPV: 6,000gp

 

General (Ring)

Magic rings appear indistinguishable from ordinary finger jewellery of varying types, though a Detect Magic spell cast upon them will cause them to radiate a magic aura. With the exception of a wish spell, the only way to determine the function of a magic ring is to put it on.

A maximum of two rings can be worn by any PC or NPC at a time; only one ring may be worn per hand. Attempting to wear additional magic rings will render all worn magical rings useless. Magic rings worn on toes or as earrings will not function.

Unless noted otherwise, the abilities a ring grants function as if cast by a 12th level spell caster, or the minimum level required to cast the spell if greater than 12th.

Because of the innate magical resistance of dwarfs, gnomes, and halflings; magic rings have a 20% chance per use of not working at all and, if cursed, the curse will fail. In such a case the wearer recognises the cursed properties of the ring and can easily remove it from his or her finger.

system.description:
Allowed Classes

AFPR

[Foundry Note: this weapon won't show any damage on the combat tab because the damage stats are on the ammunition it uses.

Also, a common houserule in advanced games was that a crossbow's range is not reduced to feet indoors/underground.- Ed.]

 

Allowed Classes

AFPR

 

Details

Some specially-made bows (sold at special cost if at all—GM's discretion) permit the user to add his or her strength bonus to damage inflicted with the weapon. 

Heavy crossbows may not be used from horseback; only a footman can brace them correctly before firing.

 

Range Penalties

Range as Missile To-Hit Penalty
Short (1-60 ft) None
Medium (61-120 ft) -2
Long (121-180 ft) -5

[Foundry Note: artificially replicate the weight-negating aspect of the bag of holding by setting the equipped status in inventory to "not carried". - Ed.]

 

Allowed Classes

Any

 

Details

A most wonderful item, this is a baglarger on the inside than on the outside. This magical sack also reduces the apparent weight of the contents of the bag.

Bag capacity, volume, weight, and apparent weight all vary by type-listed on the table below. Overloading the bag destroys both bag and contents, as does piercing the bag from either without or within. Turning a bag inside out empties all contents out onto the ground and the bag cannot be used again until it is turned back.

A living creature can be placed into the bag but there is only enough air to sustain for 10 minutes, after which the creature will suffocate and die.

The extra-dimensional space of the bag of holding is incompatible with that of the portable hole. Placing a bag of holding into a portable hole will open a rift into the Astral Plane and suck both objects and their content into Astral space, lost forever.

If a portable hole is placed into a bag of holding, a gate into the Astral Plane is opened, destroying both objects and pulling anyone standing within 10 ft into the Astral Plane.

Type: I

Weight, lbs: 15

Capacity, lbs: 250

Capacity, cubic ft: 30
Capacity: 1/4 (0.25) cu. ft. or 2.5 lbs
Capacity: 3 cu. ft. or 30 lbs
Capacity: 4 cu. ft. or 40 lbs

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables-gm.RollTable.eQfS5HAaaRGv3TQj]{Magic Arrow - destroyed/lost on miss?}

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables-gm.RollTable.LB1fG2GjjZSSDJgr]{Magic Arrow - misses recovered after combat}
Note: if carrying light bolts, its max weight is 4 lbs.
Auto-created for Crossbow, Heavy +1
Auto-created for Sword, Two-Handed +1

Foundry Note: Once the lantern is in a character's inventory, go into the cast action and set to Resource Item in the dropdown to "Oil, Lamp (per pint)".  Use the cast action to deplete pints of oil in inventory.   Target the lantern holder and and apply the light effect to them to create light on the map for the duration (24 turns). - Ed.]

 

General

Spotlight lanterns put forth a focused beam of illumination 80 ft long and burn out in 24 turns (4 hours).

actionGroups.name: Lantern, spotlight: Spotlight (4 Hours)
actionGroups.description:
Foundry Note: Once the lantern is in a character's inventory, go into the cast action and set to Resource Item in the dropdown to "Oil, Lamp (per pint)".  Use the cast action to deplete pints of oil in inventory.   Target the lantern holder and and apply the light effect to them to create light on the map for the duration (24 turns). - Ed.]

 

General

Spotlight lanterns put forth a focused beam of illumination 80 ft long and burn out in 24 turns (4 hours).

system.description:
[Foundry Note: the system will want this assigned to a proficiency.  If you as GM want to closely track WP points (and so don't want to create an unnecessary proficiency for this item that would skew the "count") then it can be assigned to any proficiency an actor already has, such as grappling or brawling.  It doesn't really matter which proficiency, it's just an assignment to remove the non-WP penalty the system defaults to on any item usable as a "weapon".

If a direct hit is scored, apply the ongoing effect in the same round you apply the direct "weapon" damage. - Ed.]

 

Allowed Classes

All

 

Details

The GM may use some form of scatter table to determine where misses land.

See Actions tab for ongoing damage effect.  Apply when rolling the normal damage above as the ongoing damage starts the following round.

 

Range as Missile To-Hit Penalty
Short (1-10 ft) None
Medium (11-20 ft) -2
Long (21-30 ft) -5

system.description:
@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables.RollTable.LkUCtqcIYSzHjPAZ]{Potions/Oils/Elixers - Onset Time After Use}

[Foundry Note: the half-drink aspect of potions is handled by giving potions 2 charges, so that half drinks can cost 1 charge and register against the total.  Going this route means the "empty" potion item will need to be manually deleted from inventory once all charges are used, however. 

It is suggested a character benefitting from potions of longevity record the cumulative age reversed, in case it's all reapplied.  Also, there is no "half-drink" for this potion. - Ed.]

 

Allowed Classes

Any

 

General

This potion makes the drinker [[/roll 1d12]] years younger. This restored youth is possible not only for natural ageing, but also for ageing from magic or creature effects.

There is some small danger however, since each time a potion of longevity is consumed there is a cumulative 1% probability that all previous age reversals from potions of this type will be negated, raising the character's age to the age he or she would be without the effects of the potions.

It is not possible to drink this potion in increments.
system.dmonlytext:
GPV: 1,000gp

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables-gm.RollTable.rwszf5JfBY1KgHyE]{Potion - Admixture Results}

(Foundry Note: the admixture rule is intended for use with potions that persist concurrently in the body.  It is suggested that potions which apply their benefit and then do not persist (and can't be dispelled) were not intended to be used with that table, as the context of  "permanent" table results makes evident.  However the materials are silent on this point and as such each GM may determine differently - Ed.)

Allowed Classes

General

This potion makes the drinker [[/roll 1d12]] years younger. This restored youth is possible not only for natural ageing, but also for ageing from magic or creature effects.

There is some small danger however, since each time a potion of longevity is consumed there is a cumulative 1% probability that all previous age reversals from potions of this type will be negated, raising the character's age to the age he or she would be without the effects of the potions.

It is not possible to drink this potion in increments.

system.description:
[Foundry Note: it is a common houserule that half-orcs are similar to elves in having spirits instead of souls, so some GMs rule they can't be raised either. - Ed.] 

 

General

The eerie, keening incantation of this spell calls a soul back from the afterlife, literally bringing the dead back to life.

Elves, as they do not have souls, cannot be brought back to life in this manner, but:

  • humans
  • half-elves
  • half-orcs
  • gnomes
  • dwarfs
  • halflings

can all be raised from the dead by means of this spell.

[H]e or she will be unable to engage in strenuous activity (such as combat, study, or spell casting) for a period of time equal to one day for each day that he or she was dead.

Perhaps mercifully, the spell erases the returning character's memory concerning any places his or her soul may have visited following death.

The reverse of the spell is Slay Living.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The longer a soul has been departed from the material plane, the more difficult it is to call it back; a cleric can summon back a soul that has been dead no more days than the cleric's level. In other words, a cleric of tenth level can raise a person who has been dead no more than ten days, but an eleventh level cleric can raise a person who has been dead eleven days.

The raised person must survive a system shock saving throw in order to return to life.

 

Combat Effects

Raise Dead can instantly destroy most kinds of corporeal undead creatures (exception: it does not destroy liches). Incorporeal undead, such as ghosts or spectres, are immune.

This use is treated the same as the Slay Living spell in terms of saving throws and damage.

REFERENCED TEXT:

...if the throw fails, the subject dies. If the saving throw succeeds, the target will still sustain [[/roll 2d8+1]] points of damage...

actions.name: Raise Dead vs Corporeal Undead
actions.misc:
Casting Instructions (if used as attack)

  • Target an undead actor
  • Cast the spell to burn the memory slot or item charge (this may already have been done)
  • If the save is successful, click the "Damage (Save Made)" action
  • If the save fails, click the "Damage (Save Failed)" action and remove the undead actor from the combat tracker

actionGroups.name: Raise Dead (S): Raise Dead
actionGroups.description:
[Foundry Note: it is a common houserule that half-orcs are similar to elves in having spirits instead of souls, so some GMs rule they can't be raised either. - Ed.] 

 

General

The eerie, keening incantation of this spell calls a soul back from the afterlife, literally bringing the dead back to life.

Elves, as they do not have souls, cannot be brought back to life in this manner, but:

  • humans
  • half-elves
  • half-orcs
  • gnomes
  • dwarfs
  • halflings

can all be raised from the dead by means of this spell.

[H]e or she will be unable to engage in strenuous activity (such as combat, study, or spell casting) for a period of time equal to one day for each day that he or she was dead.

Perhaps mercifully, the spell erases the returning character's memory concerning any places his or her soul may have visited following death.

The reverse of the spell is Slay Living.

 

Saves and Other Impediments

The longer a soul has been departed from the material plane, the more difficult it is to call it back; a cleric can summon back a soul that has been dead no more days than the cleric's level. In other words, a cleric of tenth level can raise a person who has been dead no more than ten days, but an eleventh level cleric can raise a person who has been dead eleven days.

The raised person must survive a system shock saving throw in order to return to life.

 

Combat Effects

Raise Dead can instantly destroy most kinds of corporeal undead creatures (exception: it does not destroy liches). Incorporeal undead, such as ghosts or spectres, are immune.

This use is treated the same as the Slay Living spell in terms of saving throws and damage.

REFERENCED TEXT:

...if the throw fails, the subject dies. If the saving throw succeeds, the target will still sustain [[/roll 2d8+1]] points of damage...

system.description:
[Foundry Note: This is a Container-item that can be used on a character sheet to hold items carried on the horse (switch their status to "not carried" so their weight doesn't accumulate on the PC or NPC actor).  If the animal is needed for combat purposes, the actor linked below can be pulled on to the map/combat tracker with stats adjusted as appropriate. - Ed.]

 

In 1st Edition AD&D, according to the Monster Manual (1977), a hippogriff can carry approximately 500 pounds maximum weight, including rider and gear.

Details (Monster Manual, p. 53):

  • A hippogriff is described as having a maximum load limit of 500 lbs.

  • The creature itself typically weighs around 1,000 lbs.

  • They can comfortably carry a rider wearing armor and additional equipment, provided the total load doesn't exceed their 500 lb capacity.

Allowed Classes

Any

 

Details

[Foundry Note: a passive effect negating necrotic damage and providing a +25 save bonus to the necromancy school of spells is provided, but all other benefits must be manually applied (and each absorption event manually tracked against the pool of 12 charges held in the empty cast action). - Ed.]

A beetle shaped pin that, if held or worn for at least 1 round, communicates its ability to the person holding it.

The scarab will absorb the following when directed at the wielder:

  • any death magic (being magic that directly causes death, such as a Death Spell)
  • energy draining attacks
  • negative energy effects

Petrifaction effects, for example, or effects that kill through hp loss rather than instant death, are unaffected by the scarab.

After absorbing 12 such attacks, the scarab crumbles into worthless powder.

actionGroups.name: Scarab of Protection
actionGroups.description:

Details

system.description:
@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables-gm.RollTable.eQfS5HAaaRGv3TQj]{Magic Arrow - destroyed/lost on miss?}

@UUID[Compendium.osric-compendium.rolltables-gm.RollTable.LB1fG2GjjZSSDJgr]{Magic Arrow - misses recovered after combat}

Allowed Classes

CFPR

Clerics, Fighters, Illusionists and Magic Users may create strongholds at various levels.

Clerics

When a cleric attains ninth level, he or she has accumulated sufficient divine favour and mortal renown to found a temple/stronghold. Such places are normally carved from the wilderness, in the same manner as a fighter establishes a freehold. For a cleric to assume the leadership of an existing temple, the details are left to the discretion of the GM; a level somewhat higher than ninth might be required. Whether the cleric establishes a stronghold or a temple, followers and acolytes will flock to the cleric’s banner.

Fighters

A fighter of 9th level or higher who has built a castle and cleared a wide area around it of monsters (at least a 20 mile radius), will attract a body of mercenaries to his or her service, provided that these are paid a fair wage. He or she will also be able to tax each freeholder, at up to the maximum rate of 1 gp per month per resident. Some players may choose to retire a character at this point, satisfied that the character has entered the historical records and legends of the campaign world. Others may choose to view the stronghold merely as the first step toward the pinnacles of mythic power. Such player-held castles and villages provide a higher-level party with a base for adventures, a stronghold against enemies, and possibly the introduction of feudal politics and war into their already-eventful lives.

Illusionsts and Magic Users

An illusionist (at 10th level) or a magic user (at 11th level) may establish a stronghold, usually a tower or small keep, as a fighter does.

The egg is impressive, nearly two feet tall, shimmering with polished silver. Its surface is cool, patterned in faint, swirling frost-like designs that subtly shift as you move around it. Holding it, you sense an unmistakable aura of ancient magic and elemental purity.
system.dmonlytext:
Appearance of a Silver Dragon Egg

  • Size & Shape:
    The egg is large and robust, typically 2 to 2½ feet tall and about 18 inches wide, shaped like a graceful oval with smoothly rounded ends.

  • Color & Texture:
    Its surface resembles polished silver, smooth, reflective, and gently gleaming. Under moonlight or magical illumination, the egg seems to glow softly with an internal radiance, giving it an ethereal appearance.

  • Shell Details:
    Close inspection reveals delicate swirling patterns reminiscent of frost or ice crystals etched across the surface, forming intricate designs that shift slightly when viewed from different angles.

  • Temperature:
    The egg feels consistently cool to the touch, maintaining a temperature slightly below room temperature, regardless of its surroundings.

  • Aura:
    Detect Magic reveals a strong magical aura of Good alignment and elemental magic, indicative of its draconic nature.


Suggested Cost (AD&D 1st Ed.):

  • Approximately 15,000–25,000 gold pieces, though possibly far more to the right buyer.
  • Realistically, most reputable groups (especially lawful good temples or powerful wizards) would pay generously, even more than typical "market value," to ensure the egg is safely returned to dragons or raised appropriately.
  • Evil characters, if they can find a suitable buyer, might sell such eggs on black markets for significantly more.

Hatching a Silver Dragon Egg

Requirements & Conditions:

  1. Incubation Conditions:

    • Maintain at a cool, elevated environment—such as a mountain peak cave, icy cavern, or similar place mimicking a silver dragon's natural nesting area.
    • Ideal temperature: Around 40°F to 55°F, consistently maintained.
    • Periodically exposed to moonlight, especially under the full moon, aiding its magical vitality.

  2. Incubation Time:

    • Typically requires between 12 to 18 months to hatch, depending on the egg's initial maturity when found. (If unknown, the DM can roll randomly or select a 15-month average incubation.)

  3. Magical Assistance (Optional, but strongly recommended):

    • Clerical or Druidic support: Regular blessings or gentle healing magic may encourage proper growth.
    • Wizards or druids may assist by periodically casting gentle elemental magic or enchantments to mimic the egg's natural environment (like Control Temperature, 10' Radius or similar spells).

  4. Special Considerations:

    • Mishandling, severe temperature fluctuations, or rough treatment could result in death or a stunted hatchling.
    • Evil rituals or attempts to corrupt the egg invariably fail, often triggering the attention (and wrath) of good-aligned dragons or their allies.

Hatching Procedure

  • After approximately 12–18 months, the egg will hatch naturally if conditions have been maintained.
  • When hatching:
    • The hatchling emerges healthy, roughly the size of a large dog (about 2 to 3 feet long).
    • It immediately bonds to the first creatures it sees, establishing a powerful initial relationship.
    • It speaks Draconic instinctively and has a rudimentary understanding of Common or alignment languages soon after hatching.
    • Must be fed fresh meat, fish, or magical sustenance regularly, requiring attentive, conscientious care.

nwp.name: Riding, Land-Based
nwp.description: Those skilled in land riding are proficient in the art of riding and handling horses or other types of ground mounts. When the proficiency slot is filled, the character must declare which type of mount he is proficient in.

nwp.name: Stonemasonry
nwp.description: A stonemason is able to build structures from stone so that they last many years. He can do simple stone carvings, such as lettering, columns, and flourishes. The stone can be mortared, carefully fitted and chinked with rocks and earth, or loosely fitted and earth-filled.

nwp.name: Animal Handling
nwp.description: Proficiency in this area enables a character to exercise a greater-than-normal degree of control over pack animals and beasts of burden. A successful proficiency check indicates that the character has succeeded in calming an excited or agitated animal.
